New Colombian Obstacles In Fighting Drug Traffic The United States is committing more than $1 billion to Colombia's struggle against drug trafficking and armed groups responsible for drug production just as the government in Colombia is stumbling politically and the police chief who did the most to win American trust has stepped down.

New North Korea Opportunities American corporations based in Seoul are beginning to assess opportunities in a country that has been out of bounds for five decades.
South Korea is scaling down its 50th anniversary commemoration of the Korean War in light of the new developments with the North.
Peaceful Zimbabwe Vote Zimbabwe held long-awaited national elections. Despite weeks of political unrest, early voting was reported free of the brazen intimidation that marked the campaign.

Shoring Up Mexican Economy Mexican economists are surprisingly united in feeling that the economy is strong enough during this presidential campaign season to keep any disturbance caused by the handover of power from becoming disaster.

Human Trafficking Networks Trafficking in people is now the fastest-growing business of organized crime, and it is being run by new, barely understood networks, a top official at the United Nations said.
NATIONAL

Larger Drug Benefits Proposed by Clinton President Clinton has announced a major change in his proposal for Medicare drug benefits, making it more generous to millions of elderly people and more costly to the federal government. The plan would cost $79 billion over five years, or more than twice as much as the $38 billion proposal he sent Congress as part of his budget request in February.

Prices on Internet Rise Internet retailers are trying many tactics to reassure worried investors, like laying off workers and raising advertising prices. And after long offering deep discounts, they are bringing prices back up.
Governor Faces Crisis Gov. Mike Foster of Louisiana, who once had high approval ratings, is facing a decline in popularity as his state hits an economic crisis.
Dying Alone in San Francisco In San Francisco a relatively large number of people are dying alone, with no one to arrange their funerals or settle their estates.
Hispanic Voters Courted Hispanics, a fast-growing bloc of voters, are being aggressively courted by presidential candidates and gaining a new electoral leverage.
Fund-Raiser in Chief President Clinton has been on the road, using his marquee value to raise millions of dollars for the Democratic Party and its candidates.
NEW YORK/REGION

Police Have Not Relaxed Grip, People on the Streets Say In interviews with some 200 people in all five boroughs, most of those who have substantial contact with police officers said they did not share the perception that the Police Department has relaxed its enforcement tactics in the face of criticism.

Gay Pride Parade's Ranks Grow Thirty years ago, about 200 men and women marched in the city's first gay pride parade. When that same parade steps off at noon today, its ranks will include the first lady of the United States and the mayor of New York, and it will count among its sponsors United Airlines and Budweiser.
In Albany, Civility and Progress The legislative session that wound to a close in Albany on Friday ended with an extraordinary number of agreements on big issues.
